body.content:
To get a very basic overview of a table's content, you can simply count all records contained in the table. This is the number of space missions between 1957 and Aug. 2020. Count them and name the result launches.

How many launches are in the space_raw table?

solution.content: SELECT count(*) as launches FROM space_raw;

body.content:
When did the first space mission take place? Where did it start and what are the mission details?

Query only the requested information from the database

solution.content: SELECT datum, location, detail FROM space_raw ORDER BY datum ASC LIMIT 1;

name: First NASA Mission

body.content:
In the last exercise, you loaded the first space mission details from the database. This event started the space race in 1957. When did NASA join?

Load all available data of the first NASA mision.

solution.content: SELECT * FROM space_raw WHERE company_name='NASA' ORDER BY datum ASC LIMIT 1;

hint: The company or organization operating a space mission is stored in the company_name attribute.

name: Companies

body.content:
How many different companies and organisations started a space mission?

Count the number of different companies and name the result companies.

solution.content: SELECT count(DISTINCT company_name) as companies FROM space_raw;

hint: You can solve this with a GROUP BY over only one column. Easier and faster is to learn about the DISTINCT command.

name: Spaceports

body.content:
From how many different spaceports were space missions started?

Count the number of different spaceports and name the result spaceports

solution.content: SELECT count(DISTINCT location) as space_ports FROM space_raw;

hint: You can solve this with a GROUP BY over only one column. Easier and faster is to learn about the DISTINCT command.

body.content:
Which five of the different companies launched the most space missions?

Group the missions by company and reduce the result to the total amount of missions. Name the needed two attributes company, missions

solution.content: SELECT company_name as company, count(company_name) as missions FROM space_raw GROUP BY company_name ORDER BY missions DESC LIMIT 5;

body.content:
Which five of the different space ports launched the most space missions?

Group the missions by location and reduce the result to the total amount of missions. Name the needed two attributes location, missions

solution.content: SELECT location, count(location) as missions FROM space_raw GROUP BY location ORDER BY missions DESC LIMIT 5;

name: Historic most frequent space port

body.content:
Which five of the different space ports launched the most space missions during the first 10 years of the space race (1957 - 1967)?

Group the missions by location and reduce the result to the total amount of missions. Name the needed two attributes location, missions

solution.content:
SELECT
	location,
	count(location) as missions 
FROM space_raw 
WHERE datum < '1968-01-01 00:00:00'
GROUP BY location
ORDER BY missions DESC
LIMIT 5;

hint: Filtering data using WHERE can not only compare two attributes, but also an attribute and a static value. Datetimes can be given as a ISO-8601 string or locale, without explicit type case. An example is: '2013-09-24 11:23'.
